thread.title: ‘1mn penguins’ descend on Argentina in spectacular scene (VIDEOS, PHOTOS)
thread.title_full: ‘1mn penguins’ descend on Argentina in spectacular scene (VIDEOS, PHOTOS)

author: RT
title: ‘1mn penguins’ descend on Argentina in spectacular scene (VIDEOS, PHOTOS)
text:
‘1mn penguins’ descend on Argentina in spectacular scene (VIDEOS, PHOTOS)   23:51 Edited time: 20 Feb, 2017 00:06 Get short URL Over 1 million of the flightless birds are reported to have landed onshore in Argentina © brendug / Instagram Over one million penguins arrived on Punta Tombo, Argentina in what is thought to be a record number, resulting in stunning displays of wildlife along the shoreline. Over a million of #penguins fill the #natural reserve of Punta Tombo #Patagonia #Argentina . Would you like to see it yourself? Contact us! pic.twitter.com/dD80KAnayn — Across Argentina (@acrossar) February 17, 2017 
Often seen in parts of southern Argentina and Chile, the numerous small inlets of Punta Tombo in Argentina’s southeast region make a perfect breeding ground for the Magellanic penguins due to the large quantities of sardines and anchovies found close to shore. A post shared by Hilda* (@hildavida) on Feb 18, 2017 at 4:03am PST A post shared by Fer Membribes (@fermembribes) on Feb 18, 2017 at 12:34pm PST 
Measuring about 45cm (17in) tall and weighing around 4kg (9lbs), the magellanic penguin sports a large white crescent of feathers on their breast, and have distinctive pink coloring on their faces. A post shared by Serhiy Martynenko (@ss_mart) on Feb 19, 2017 at 10:54am PST A post shared by Sasha Belova (@wonka_) on Feb 19, 2017 at 1:24pm PST A post shared by Hilda* (@hildavida) on Feb 18, 2017 at 3:54am PST 
Tens of thousands of tourists flock to the peninsula each year to catch a glimpse of the flightless birds but this year is extra special as locals say more than one million of the birds have arrived - a record number - according to AP . Please don’t tell Donald Trump that a gathering of penguins in Argentina outnumbered his inauguration. Our military doesn’t want that war. https://t.co/tcsQe1ogEE — Jason Karsh (@jkarsh) February 18, 2017 
While not yet an endangered species, a number of Magellanic penguins die annually when they become tangled in the nets of commercial fisheries. Its population has been particularly impacted by oil spills in the past, with some 40,000 Magellanic penguins killed each year until the mid-1990s, according to Argentina’s Wildlife Conservation Society. This has improved over the last 20 years, however, with “less than one or two thousand oiled each year.”
